examples.title: Set Equality via Extensionality
examples.statement: Show that $\{1, 2, 3\} = \{3, 2, 1\}$ using the axiom of extensionality.

steps.title: State the axiom
steps.content: Two sets $A$ and $B$ are equal iff for every object $x$, $x \in A \Leftrightarrow x \in B$.

steps.title: Verify membership
steps.content: $1 \in \{1,2,3\}$ and $1 \in \{3,2,1\}$. Similarly for $2$ and $3$. Any other object is in neither set.

solution.conclusion: By extensionality, $\{1, 2, 3\} = \{3, 2, 1\}$. Order does not matter in sets.

exercises.statement: If $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq A$, prove that $A = B$.

steps.title: Use definition of subset
steps.content: $A \subseteq B$ means $x \in A \Rightarrow x \in B$. $B \subseteq A$ means $x \in B \Rightarrow x \in A$.

steps.title: Combine
steps.content: Together, $x \in A \Leftrightarrow x \in B$, which by extensionality means $A = B$.

solution.conclusion: If $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq A$, then $A = B$.

examples.title: Russell's Paradox
examples.statement: Explain why the 'set of all sets that do not contain themselves' leads to a contradiction.

steps.title: Define the set
steps.content: Let $R = \{x : x \notin x\}$, the set of all sets that do not contain themselves.

steps.title: Ask whether $R \in R$
steps.content: If $R \in R$, then by definition $R \notin R$. If $R \notin R$, then by definition $R \in R$.

solution.conclusion: Either answer leads to contradiction. This shows naive set theory is inconsistent.

exercises.statement: Using the axiom of regularity, prove that no set can contain itself: $x \notin x$ for all sets $x$.

steps.title: Consider $\{x\}$
steps.content: By regularity, every non-empty set $A$ contains an element $y$ such that $y \cap A = \emptyset$.

steps.title: Apply to $\{x\}$
steps.content: If $x \in x$, then $\{x\}$ is non-empty. The only element is $x$, so $x \cap \{x\} = \emptyset$. But $x \in x$ and $x \in \{x\}$, so $x \in x \cap \{x\}$, contradiction.

exercises.statement: Let $f: A \to B$ and $g: B \to C$ be functions. Show that $g \circ f: A \to C$ is a function.

steps.title: Verify well-defined
steps.content: Since $f(x) \in B$ and $g: B \to C$, we have $g(f(x)) \in C$. Each $x \in A$ is mapped to exactly one element of $C$.

solution.conclusion: $g \circ f: A \to C$ is a well-defined function.

exercises.statement: Let $f: X \to Y$ be a function and let $A, B \subseteq X$. Prove that $f(A \cup B) = f(A) \cup f(B)$.

steps.title: Show $f(A \cup B) \subseteq f(A) \cup f(B)$
steps.content: If $y \in f(A \cup B)$, then $y = f(x)$ for some $x \in A \cup B$. Thus $x \in A$ or $x \in B$, so $y \in f(A)$ or $y \in f(B)$.

steps.title: Show $f(A) \cup f(B) \subseteq f(A \cup B)$
steps.content: If $y \in f(A)$, then $y = f(x)$ for some $x \in A \subseteq A \cup B$, so $y \in f(A \cup B)$. Similarly for $y \in f(B)$.

steps.title: Take $(a, x) \in A \times (B \cup C)$
steps.content: Then $a \in A$ and $x \in B \cup C$. So $x \in B$ or $x \in C$. Thus $(a,x) \in A \times B$ or $(a,x) \in A \times C$.

steps.title: Conversely
steps.content: If $(a,x) \in (A \times B) \cup (A \times C)$, then $a \in A$ and $x \in B$ or $x \in C$, so $x \in B \cup C$.
